questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements are false about the ciliary body?

options.a: It consists of the pars plana and pars plicata.
options.b: Contraction of the ciliary body helps in accommodation.
options.d: It derives its blood supply from short posterior ciliary arteries.

questions.explanation:
The ciliary body derives its blood supply from the long posterior ciliary artery and anterior ciliary 
arteries, which form the major arterial circle at the root of the iris. The ciliary body is a triangular structure that begins at the base of the iris and becomes 
continuous with the choroid at the ora serrata. It is approximately 6–6.5 mm in an 
anteroposterior dimension. It consists of an anterior portion called the pars plicata and a posterior portion called the pars 
plana (option A). The pars plicata contains approximately 70 finger-like projections called ciliary 
processes, which are covered by the ciliary body epithelium. These processes secrete aqueous 
humor (option C). The pars plana is the flat part of the ciliary body and ends at the ora serrata. The smooth muscle of the ciliary body is divided into three groups of fibers: • Outer longitudinal portion that attaches anteriorly to the scleral spur and trabecular meshwork 
fibers 339 
Sold by @itachibot • Middle oblique portion • Inner circular portion (responsible for accommodation) (option B)

questions.question: Question 2: A 3-year-old child with the following finding has high myopia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image shows corectopia, an abnormal eccentrically placed pupil. It can be a congenital anomaly or an acquired defect with essential iris atrophy. It may be 
associated with high myopia or ectopia lentis, among other conditions.

questions.question:
Question 3: 333 
Sold by @itachibot A patient presents to the casualty after ocular trauma with a D-shaped pupil. What is the 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A D-shaped pupil is seen in iridodialysis. Iridodialysis is the dis-insertion of the iris root from the ciliary body attachment. It may occur 
following ocular trauma. A red reflex can be obtained from the peripheral gap in the iris. The given image depicts iridodialysis and a D-shaped pupil. 340 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is the pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis?
questions.explanation:
The pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis is keratic precipitates (KP). Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits at the back of cornea. The composition of 
KPs varies with the type of uveitis. Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris to the pars plicata of the 
ciliary body. Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis: • Corneal signs • Corneal edema • Keratic precipitates (Pathognomonic) • Posterior corneal opacity • Anterior chamber signs • Aqueous cells • Aqueous flare (earliest sign) • Hypopyon • Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae • Iris signs • Loss of normal pattern • Change in color • Iris nodules (Koeppe, Busacca) • Posterior synechiae • Neovascularization 341 
Sold by @itachibot • Pupillary signs • Constricted pupil • Irregular pupil shape • Ectropion of pupillary margin • Occlusion pupillae

questions.question: Question 5: What is the first sign a patient with anterior uveitis may show?
questions.explanation:
Aqueous flare is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis. Aqueous flare is due to the leakage of protein particles into the aqueous humor from damaged 
blood vessels. It is demonstrated on the slit-lamp examination. It is based on the principle 
of Brownian movement or Tyndall phenomenon. Aqueous flare is usually marked in non-granulomatous uveitis and minimal in granulomatous 
uveitis. The presence of cells in the anterior chamber denotes an active inflammatory process. The image below is a high magnification slit-beam photograph 3×1 mm in size in a darkroom 
showing the presence of cells and flare. 342 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 34-year-old lady presents with eye pain, photophobia, and red-eye. The slit-lamp 
examination finding is shown below. On which layer of the cornea are these present? 334 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Eye pain, photophobia and red-eye along with the slit lamp finding of keratic precipitates suggests 
a diagnosis of acute anterior uveitis. Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular 
deposits occurring at the back of the corneal endothelium. Keratuc precipitates are arranged in a triangular fashion, occupying the center and inferior 
parts of the cornea (Arlt's triangle).

questions.question:
Question 7: You are evaluating a 45-year-old man admitted for acute anterior uveitis. What is the 
pupillary shape you expect to find in his eyes?
questions.explanation:
The pupil in acute anterior uveitis is constricted (pupillary sphincter spasm), irregular and 
sluggishly reactive to light In an acute attack of uveitis, the pupil is irregular and narrow due to irritation of sphinchter 
pupillae. Pupillary signs in chronic anterior uveitis is as follows: • Festooned pupil results from the application of mydriatics in segmental posterior synechiae. • Occlusio pupillae results when the pupil is completely occluded due to the organization of the 
exudates across the pupillary area. • Seclusio pupillae due to ring synechiae, that prevent the circulation of aqueous humor from the 
posterior chamber to the anterior chamber. The image below shows a festooned pupil. 343 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient with sarcoidosis shows Koeppe's nodules on ophthalmologic examination. Where 
are these seen?
questions.explanation:
Koeppe's nodules and Bussaca's nodules develop on the iris in granulomatous uveitis. Granulomatous uveitis is a chronic proliferative inflammation seen in reponse to tuberculosis, 
leprosy, syphilis and sarcoidosis. Infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, with proliferation 
of mononuclear cells leads to the formation of iris nodule. Koeppe's nodules are seen at 
the pupillary margin. Bussaca's nodules are seen on the peripheral part of the anterior surface of 
iris.

questions.question: Question 9: What is the type of synechiae formed in iris bombe?
questions.explanation:
344 
Sold by @itachibot Iris bombe formation is due to the development of annular or ring synechiae. Annular posterior/ring synechiae are 360° adhesions of the pupillary margin to the anterior 
capsule of the lens. They prevent the circulation of aqueous humor from the posterior chamber to 
the anterior chamber (seclusio pupillae). Thus, the aqueous collects behind the iris and pushes it 
anteriorly leading to iris bombe. This is usually followed by a rise in intraocular pressure. The 
anterior chamber is funnel-shaped when ring synechiae are present. The image below shows iris bombe on slit lamp examination.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 38-year-old woman has been having repeated episodes of red-eye, eye pain, and blurred 
vision. She is diagnosed with chronic granulomatous uveitis. Which of the following is not a 
cause?
questions.explanation:
Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a type of non-granulomatous uveitis. 345 
Sold by @itachibot Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidious progressive anterior uveitis. It is mostly 
unilateral and associated with early cataract formation. Stellate keratic precipitates are seen and 
there is a notable absence of posterior synechiae. Causes for chronic granulomatous uveitis include sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, herpes simplex, 
herpes zoster, syphilis, leprosy, brucellosis and phacoanaphylactic.

questions.question:
Question 11: Intermediate uveitis is also called as  
.
questions.explanation:
Intermediate uveitis refers to pars planitis. It involves inflammation of the pars plana. The uvea consists of the iris, ciliary body and choroid. Inflammation of uveal tissue is called 
uveitis. It can be classified anatomically as follows: • Anterior uveitis: Inflammation of iris and pars plicata, consisting of iritis, iridocyclitis and 
anterior cyclitis • Intermediate uveitis: Inflammation of pars plana (pars planitis) • Posterior uveitis: Inflammation of the retina with or without involvement of the retina. It 
includes choroiditis, chorioretinitis, retinochoroiditis and neuroretinitis. • Panuveitis Pathological classification divides uveitis into suppurative and nonsuppurative uveitis. 
Nonsuppurative uveitis is further classified into nongranulomatous and granulomatous uveitis. The image is a schematic representation of the anatomical classification of uveitis.

questions.question:
Question 12: In a patient with intermediate uveitis, which of the following is a pathognomonic examination 
finding?
questions.explanation:
Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. 346 
Sold by @itachibot Snow banking refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without 
peripheral retinal periphlebitis. Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation of the pars plana and presents with retrolental flare, few 
keratic precipitates, vitreous cells and snow-ball opacities (Ant’s egg opacities). These are typical 
exudates present near the ora serrata in the inferior quadrant. Treatment of intermediate uveitis is by the Kaplan 4-step protocol: • Periocular steroid: Sub tenon injection of triamcinolone acetate • Systemic steroid • Cryotherapy over snow banking • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.question:
Question 13: While studying a cohort of patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis, you are evaluating the 
risk of iridocyclitis among the different subtypes of JIA. Which subtype has the highest risk of 
iridocyclitis associated?
questions.explanation:
ANA-positive oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is associated with the highest risk 
for iridocyclitis (uveitis). A positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test result confers increased risk for uveitis in children with 
JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination. Uveitis in JIA is characteristically chronic, 
non-granulomatous, and bilateral. It presents as a white eye without congestion- white uveitis. 
Complications include complicated cataracts, secondary glaucoma, and band-shaped keratopathy. Note: Intraocular lens (IOL) implantation can be considered in most pediatric patients with 
well-controlled uveitis, but JIA-associated uveitis should be considered as a relative 
contraindication.

questions.question: Question 14: Where is Amsler's sign seen?
questions.explanation:
347 
Sold by @itachibot Amsler sign is seen in Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI). Amsler sign is the hemorrhage caused by cataract surgery in FHI. During cataract surgery, fine 
filiform hemorrhages from the opposite angle are seen to occur as soon as the anterior chamber is 
opened. This is due to neovascularization. Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidiously progressive, non- granulomatous anterior 
uveitis, that is usually unilateral. Stellate KPs are seen and tiny crystals (Russell bodies) may be 
present on the iris surface. There are no posterior synechiae. Rubeosis iridis may be present. The 1st image shows Fuchs heterochromic uveitis. The right eye is normal. The left hypochromic 
eye is affected. The 2nd image shows stellate keratic precipiates.

questions.question: Question 15: What is Posner-Schlossman syndrome?

options.a: Ipsilateral optic atrophy with contralateral papilloedemac
options.b: Unilateral glaucomatous changes with mild anterior uveitis

questions.explanation:
348 
Sold by @itachibot Posner–Schlossman syndrome is characterized by unilateral glaucomatous changes with mild 
anterior uveitis. This syndrome, also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis or hypertensive uveitis, presents 
with recurrent unilateral attachs of acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) (>40 mmHg) 
changes, fine white central keratic precipitates (KPs) and mydriasis. Treatment includes topical 
corticosteroids, cycloplegics, and aqueous suppressants.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 44-year-old patient with AIDS and opportunistic infections was started on treatment. He 
develops a sterile hypopyon anterior uveitis that is suspected to be drug-induced. Which of 
the following drugs may be implicated here?
questions.explanation: Rifabutin causes uveitis in AIDS patients. Causes of drug-induced uveitis include: • Cidofovir • Rifabutin • Bisphosphonates • Oral moxifloxacin

questions.question: Question 17: Which among the following is associated with transient hypopyon syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Behcet's disease presents with recurrent iridocyclitis associated with transient hypopyon. Behcet's disease is a systemic vascular disease. It is associated with HLA B5 >> B51. Patients 
have obliterative vasculitis due to circulating immune complexes, leading to a recurrent, bilateral 
non-granulomatous uveitis. There is acute recurrent iridocyclitis, transient hypopyon, 
periphlebitis, retinitis, vitritis and cystoid macular edema (CME).

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient presents with photophobia and blurring of vision. On examination, the eye appears 
as shown below. What is the mainstay of treatment?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario of photophobia and blurring of vision along with red-eye and irregularly 
shaped pupil suggests a diagnosis of anterior uveitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of 
the treatment of uveitis. Steroids are the drug of choice in anterior uveitis. They reduce inflammation by their 
anti-inflammatory effect. Cycloplegics like 1% atropine relieve spasm of the iris sphincter and 
ciliary muscles. They prevent the formation of synechiae and reduce exudation. Systemic 
therapy includes steroids, NSAIDs, and immunosuppressants. Immunosuppressants like voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor) are used in severe cases. They are 
being studied under a program called LUMINATE. 349 
Sold by @itachibot Uveitis - Posterior and Panuveitis
